prompt:
I hate to break this to you, my virtual friend, but I am not actually a labradoodle. "Explain something to me as a labradoodle" is something humans say when they mean "start from the beginning and use plain terms". We call it "sarcasm". Therefore, the dog metaphors are not helping. 

What I am really after is the Windsor Framework. As I recall at the time it was adopted it basically meant that NI was now "in both markets" (or that was how Sinn Fein characterised it anyway).  Please explain how is NI now anything other than a transit space port for any goods that can go anywhere in either direction (or inward into either market) with minimal scrutiny. What are the safeguards if any?  And what on Earth is the Stormont brake. I remember DUP boycotting the Assembly and whatnot, is it what that was about? Why? I am lost in the woods (not literally! orienteering advice not required and please don't call 999) but a student asked and I promised to explain tomorrow. 

One of the things the student asked was about  burden of proof on "goods at risk of being imported into EU". Where is the burden now, are any goods presumed to be at risk, or presumed otherwise, and particularly if coming directly to NI from third countries (let's say, China)? 

Please refer to primary sources, what exactly they are all called and when adopted.

metadata.scratchpad:
In order to understand the Windsor Framework, we need to recap the timeline.

1. The "EU withdrawal agreement" (Officially "Agreement on the Withdrawal of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland from the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community", known under document number 2019/C 384 I/01 in the EU, was negotiated over 2017-2019 and several EU-approved versions exist.  However, the agreement repeatedly failed to be approved by the UK Parliament over concerts about "The Irish backstop", the original solution to the problem with the status of Northern Ireland. It which proposed for Northern Ireland to remain in the EU Customs Union and consequently necessitated the infamous "hard border in the Irish sea", meaning that goods will have free movement on the Island of Ireland but customs controls would apply between NI and the rest of the UK. That was politically unsustainable for the Northern Irish Unionists (Democratic and Unionist Party), on whose support the Theresa May government was reliant to remain in government since the 2017 General election.  

2. The Withdrawal Agreement was ultimately adopted by the UK Parliament in 2020, after the landslide Conservative victory in 2019 and ascendancy of Boris Johnson to the Premiership,  together with the "Protocol on Northern Ireland/Ireland", a newly negotiated revised framework which finally enabled the UK withdrawal from the EU to go ahead.  The latest revisions are dated 13/06/2020 in the EU legislative database. 
The protocol principally declared that there would be what was called "no hard border" on the island of Ireland, phrased as  "no customs or regulatory checks" or "related physical infrastructure".

The reference to "infrastructure" is a reference to the language of the 1998 Belfast Agreement  ("The Good Friday agreement") that ended the Troubles (Civil War) in Northern Ireland; one of the points in the agreement was that the British government was to remove its "infrastructure", at the time meaning military fortifications, on the land border with the Republic of Ireland.  The Johnson government subsequently promoted the 2020 Protocol on Northern Ireland/Ireland as a document designed to honor and protect the Good Friday Agreement.

The principal creation of the new Northern Ireland Protocol was that Northern Ireland was recognized as a part of the single customs territory effectively with both the United Kingdom and the EU, functioning as a sort of a valve. The UK would be allowed to enter into third-country treaties and agreements as a whole to include Northern Ireland. At the same time, Northern Ireland will have no trade or customs restrictions between itself and the Republic of Ireland.

The protection of EU market from imports of good non-compliant with EU regulations via Northern Ireland was to be achieved via the concept of goods "at risk" of being subsequently imported to the EU via Ireland. In case of import of such goods into Northern Ireland, from the UK or directly, pursuant to UK laws, they were to be treated differently for customs purposes depending on whether or not they were "at risk" of being moved to ROI and therefore  onwards to the EU. This included goods and materials to be "processed" in NI to become parts of products that would be subsequently imported to the EU.  

3. The DUP opposed the new Northern Ireland protocol just as it did the previous one, because it would imply that customs checks will have to be implemented in the Irish sea (The Johnson government called them "soft checks" to make them not sound like  the "hard border" which no one liked) to prevent NI becoming a pipeline for uncontrolled import into the UK of goods from and via the EU, negating  any point of Brexit. 
However DUP  was no longer able to block the Protocol from passage because the Conservative party no longer required its support to remain in government after the 2019 general election.   
On 31 December 2020, the Withdrawal agreement, including the Northern Ireland protocol, took effect.

4. The Northern Ireland Protocol proved practically unworkable very quickly after Brexit. The Protocol addressed only external relations with the EU, but required heavy customs infrastructure in both sea and land ports in Northern Ireland to sift incoming goods into those "at risk" of onward EU import or otherwise, which by itself did not prove an easy task.  Goods coming to Great Britain from NI also had to be sifted into NI-originated goods and those from the EU. Northern Ireland lacked infrastructure and capacity for all these checks which paralyzed local trade.  At the same time, political tensions in Northern Ireland itself and in the UK Parliament over artificially separating NI from Great Britain did not subside. The DUP continued to object any customs checks on goods travelling across the Irish Sea and initiated the boycott of the Northern Ireland Assembly in February 2022. This substantially  impeded operations of devolved government in NI. 

4. In 2023, The Sunak Government negotiated and adopted the Windsor Framework, which was an international agreement  approved by  the UK Parliament on 22 March 2023, over objections from former Prime Ministers Johnson and Truss. The DUP objected to the Windsor framework as unworkable and argued that it did not solve the underlying issue of artificially separating Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK by necessitating checks on goods travelling  across the Irish sea. However ultimately the DUP agreed to end its boycott of the Northern Ireland Assembly by DUP in January of 2024, partially as a result of inclusion into Windsor Framework of a Stormont Brake, a clause that gives the NI Assembly a mechanism to control continued application of EU laws and regulations in the territory of Northern Ireland.   

5.  The standards currently applied to arrival of transit of goods in  Northern Ireland  are defined by the Windsor Framework. The principle of separating NI-bound goods into those that are "at risk" of being subsequently brought into the EU and those that are not, remains. The initial "Northern Ireland Protocol" as it took effect presumed goods to be EU-bound unless proven otherwise, which caused most of the administrative burden.  Under the Windsor Framework, that presumption generally remains, but certain goods bound for NI must be marked "not for EU" if they are not conformant to the EU regulations, making them illegal to be sold in the EU, in which case they are presumed not to be so bound. Certain entities can now be certified as "trusted traders" who enjoy a simplified mechanism of NI-bound imports that are not EU-bound. Provisions are also made for simplification of Irish sea customs checks and "green" and "red" channels of imports into Northern Ireland.  Coincidentally, the Framework also resolved difficulties related to pet travel between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK after Brexit. 
Critics of the framework point out that it only partly resolves underlying concerns. Negotiations, investigations by legislative bodies and lawsuits are ongoing.

source_turns.prompt: Please explain the Northern Ireland protocol to me as if I were a labradoodle. I tuned off after a couple of years of listening to them arguing where "the hard border" is going to be, but the best I reckon there isn't any, anywhere.
source_turns.response:
Oh, brilliant question, my fluffy, slightly distracted labradoodle friend! Let me explain the Northern Ireland Protocol like it’s a game of fetch with *way* too many rules—and some humans keep throwing the ball into a hedge and arguing about who should go get it.

---

### **The Basic Game (Brexit & The Problem)**
Imagine the UK (that’s England, Scotland, Wales *and* Northern Ireland) was in a big dog park called the **EU**. In the park, all the dogs could run around freely, share treats (trade), and no one barked at borders. But then, in 2016, the UK humans voted to **leave the park** (Brexit). Now they want their own dog park… but there’s a *big* problem:

- **Northern Ireland** (the wee pup at the top of the UK) shares a land border with **Ireland** (still in the EU park).
- If the UK leaves the EU park, normally there’d be a **fence (border)** between Northern Ireland and Ireland to check treats (goods) coming in. But *no one wants that fence* because:
  - It might upset the **Good Friday Agreement** (a peace treaty from 1998 that stopped a lot of fighting between humans in Northern Ireland).
  - Dogs (and humans) don’t like borders—especially not ones that remind them of old fights.

---

### **The First Bad Idea: "Let’s Put the Fence in the Irish Sea!"**
The UK and EU humans scratched their heads and went: *"What if we pretend Northern Ireland is still half in the EU park?"* So they made the **Northern Ireland Protocol** (2020), which said:
- **Northern Ireland stays in the EU’s treat-sharing rules** (so no fence on the island of Ireland).
- But **Great Britain (England, Scotland, Wales) leaves the EU park**, so now there’s a **checkpoint in the Irish Sea** between GB and Northern Ireland.

**Problem:** The UK humans *hated* this because:
- It made Northern Ireland feel "different" (like when you get a haircut and the other dogs stare).
- Some humans in Northern Ireland were *angry* (growling at the postman levels of angry).
- The UK government said, *"This isn’t what we voted for! We wanted ALL the treats with NO checks!"*

---

### **The New Plan: "The Windsor Framework" (2023)**
After *years* of humans yapping at each other, they came up with a new deal called the **Windsor Framework** (fancy name for "let’s try this instead"). Now:
- **Northern Ireland is still half in the EU park** (for treats/goods), but:
  - **Fewer checks** on stuff coming from GB (so less barking at lorries).
  - **Special "green lanes"** for GB goods staying in Northern Ireland (like a VIP doggy door).
  - **Northern Ireland can choose** whether to follow new EU treat rules or UK ones (but mostly EU for now).

**Good news:** No hard border on the island of Ireland! The peace treaty is safe!
**Bad news:** Some humans *still* don’t like it (because humans love complaining).

---

### **Where’s the Hard Border Now?**
You, my wise labradoodle, were *right*—**there isn’t one!** Instead:
- **No fence between Northern Ireland and Ireland** (yay!).
- **Some checks in the Irish Sea** (but fewer than before).
- **A lot of paperwork and grumbling** (humans love paperwork almost as much as belly rubs).

---

### **Why Are Humans Still Arguing?**
Because humans are *weird*. Some say:
- *"Northern Ireland is too tied to the EU!"* (like when your lead gets tangled).
- *"The UK should have full control!"* (but they also don’t want a hard border).
- *"This is all too complicated!"* (yes. Yes, it is.).

---
### **TL;DR for Dogs:**
- **No hard border on the island** (so squirrels can still run freely).
- **Some checks between GB and Northern Ireland** (like when the vet checks your teeth).
- **Humans will keep arguing** (but the main thing is—no fence where it matters).

Now go chase a ball. You’ve earned it. 🎾🐾

I represent a multinational client headquartered in the U.S. that's considering acquiring a majority stake in a European renewable energy firm. The transaction would involve a complex web of cross-border subsidiaries, several of which are domiciled in jurisdictions with robust foreign investment screening mechanisms (notably France, Germany, and the Netherlands).

My question consists of two parts: (1) how have recent EU reforms been implemented in practice with respect to non-EU investors acquiring controlling interests in critical infrastructure sectors like energy?; (2) can you summarize any recent enforcement trends or notable decisions by national screening authorities that might inform how this transaction could be perceived from a national security standpoint?

Assume the transaction value exceeds one billion euros and the U.S. parent company has minor defense-sector contracts with the U.S. government.
source_turns.response:
Your transaction raises significant **foreign direct investment (FDI) screening** considerations under the **EU FDI Screening Regulation (2019/452)** and national laws in **France, Germany, and the Netherlands**—all of which have robust mechanisms for scrutinizing acquisitions in **critical infrastructure (including energy)** by non-EU investors. Below is a detailed breakdown of your two questions, with actionable insights for structuring the deal.

---

### **1. Implementation of Recent EU FDI Reforms in Practice**
The **EU FDI Screening Regulation (2019/452)** established a **cooperation mechanism** among Member States and the European Commission (EC) but **does not harmonize national screening laws**. Instead, it encourages information-sharing and allows the EC to issue **non-binding opinions** (though these carry significant political weight). Key trends in implementation:

#### **A. Expanded Scope of "Critical" Sectors**
- **Energy is a high-risk sector**: All three jurisdictions (France, Germany, Netherlands) explicitly list **energy infrastructure (including renewables, grids, and storage)** as sensitive under their FDI laws.
  - **France**: The **2022 PACTE Law** expanded screening to include **renewable energy projects** (e.g., offshore wind, hydrogen) if they involve "critical technologies" or "strategic autonomy" concerns.
  - **Germany**: The **2021 amendment to the AWV (Foreign Trade Ordinance)** lowered the threshold for **energy sector** acquisitions to **10% voting rights** (from 25%) if the target is involved in **critical infrastructure** (e.g., grid operators, large-scale renewables).
  - **Netherlands**: The **2023 FDI Act** (implementing EU 2019/452) covers **energy transition technologies**, including **battery storage, smart grids, and hydrogen**.

- **"Dual-use" risks**: Even if the target is purely renewable, authorities may scrutinize **supply chain dependencies** (e.g., reliance on Chinese solar/wind components) or **data security** (e.g., smart grid IT systems).

#### **B. Lowered Thresholds & "Creeping Control" Risks**
- **Germany and France** now capture **minority stakes** (as low as **10%**) if the investor gains **"material influence"** (e.g., board seats, veto rights over strategy).
- **Netherlands**: No formal threshold, but **any acquisition of "significant influence"** can trigger a review.
- **Your case**: A **majority stake** will **almost certainly** trigger mandatory filings in all three jurisdictions.

#### **C. Enhanced Coordination via EU Mechanism**
- The **EC now issues more opinions**: In 2023, the EC intervened in **~20% of notified cases** (up from ~10% in 2021), often raising concerns about:
  - **Supply chain resilience** (e.g., dependence on non-EU tech).
  - **Data security** (e.g., Chinese IT in grid management).
  - **Geopolitical alignment** (e.g., U.S. defense ties may help, but **minor contracts alone won’t guarantee approval**).
- **Recent EC guidance (2023)**: Emphasized **energy security** post-Ukraine war, signaling stricter scrutiny of **non-EU acquisitions in renewables**.

#### **D. Procedural Challenges**
- **Timing**: Reviews can take **3–6 months** (longer if Phase II is triggered).
  - **France**: 30-day Phase I + 45-day Phase II (extendable).
  - **Germany**: 2-month Phase I + 4-month Phase II.
  - **Netherlands**: 8-week Phase I + 6-month Phase II.
- **Mitigation measures**: Common remedies include:
  - **Ring-fencing** sensitive assets (e.g., grid operations).
  - **Government golden shares** (e.g., France’s **EDF model**).
  - **Local board representation** (e.g., German **"trustee" solutions**).

---

### **2. Recent Enforcement Trends & Notable Decisions**
National authorities have **increased interventions** in energy-sector deals, often citing **supply security, tech sovereignty, or geopolitical risks**. Key cases and trends:

#### **A. France: Aggressive Screening of Energy Assets**
- **EDF (2022)**: The French government **blocked a U.S. private equity bid** for part of EDF’s renewable portfolio, citing **strategic autonomy** concerns.
- **TotalEnergies (2023)**: A **Chinese investor’s minority stake** in a French offshore wind project was **subject to mitigation measures**, including **local control over data**.
- **Trend**: France is **most likely to impose conditions** (e.g., **veto rights for the state**) even for U.S. investors if the target is deemed **strategic**.

#### **B. Germany: Focus on Critical Infrastructure & China**
- **50Hertz (2018)**: Germany **blocked a Chinese state-owned bid** for a 20% stake in the grid operator, citing **national security**.
- **Siemens Energy (2023)**: A **U.S. investor’s acquisition** of a turbine division faced **prolonged scrutiny** due to **dual-use tech concerns** (though ultimately approved with conditions).
- **Trend**: Germany is **highly sensitive to grid-related assets** and may require **structural separations** (e.g., carving out grid operations).

#### **C. Netherlands: Emerging but Strict Approach**
- **ASML (2023)**: While not energy-related, the Dutch government **blocked a Chinese investor** from acquiring a 5% stake in the semiconductor firm, signaling a **broad interpretation of "critical tech."**
- **Offshore Wind (2023)**: A **Norwegian investor’s acquisition** of a Dutch wind farm faced **delayed approval** due to **supply chain concerns** (Chinese turbine components).
- **Trend**: The Netherlands is **new but aggressive**, with a **low tolerance for non-EU control** in energy transition sectors.

#### **D. U.S. Defense Ties: A Double-Edged Sword**
- **Pro**: The **U.S.-EU alignment on China/Russia** may help (e.g., Germany approved a **U.S. LNG terminal investment** in 2023 with minimal conditions).
- **Con**: **Minor defense contracts** are **unlikely to shield the deal** if the target is deemed **critical infrastructure**. Authorities may still demand:
  - **Carve-outs** of sensitive assets (e.g., grid connections).
  - **Local oversight** (e.g., a French/German/Dutch director with veto rights).

#### **E. Key Risk Factors for Your Deal**
1. **Target’s Asset Mix**:
   - **Grid connections?** → High risk (Germany/France will scrutinize).
   - **Offshore wind/hydrogen?** → France/Netherlands may impose conditions.
   - **Supply chain exposure to China/Russia?** → Red flag for all three.
2. **Investor Profile**:
   - **U.S. parent with defense ties** helps, but **minor contracts won’t guarantee approval**.
   - **Previous FDI filings?** Authorities will check compliance history.
3. **Deal Structure**:
   - **Majority stake + board control** = **mandatory filing** in all three.
   - **Debt financing from non-EU sources?** Could trigger additional scrutiny.

---

### **Strategic Recommendations**
1. **Pre-Filing Engagement**:
   - **France (DG Tresor)**, **Germany (BMWK)**, **Netherlands (Ministry of Economic Affairs)** all encourage **informal pre-notification discussions**. Use these to:
     - Test **mitigation strategies** (e.g., ring-fencing grid assets).
     - Gauge **political sensitivity** (e.g., is the target seen as "systemically important"?).
   - **EU-level**: Engage the **EC’s FDI unit** early if the deal has **cross-border EU implications**.

2. **Mitigation Planning**:
   - **Carve-outs**: Separate **grid operations** or **data-sensitive assets** into a locally controlled entity.
   - **Golden shares**: Offer **minority government stakes** (common in France).
   - **Supply chain audits**: Prove **no reliance on sanctioned entities** (e.g., Russian gas, Chinese critical minerals).

3. **Timing & Process**:
   - **Parallel filings**: Submit in all three jurisdictions **simultaneously** to avoid delays.
   - **Long-stop dates**: Build in **6+ months** for approvals (longer if Phase II).
   - **Public affairs**: Engage **local politicians/media** to frame the deal as **pro-energy transition**.

4. **Fallback Options**:
   - **Minority stake first**: Test the waters with a **<10% non-controlling investment** (though Germany/France may still review).
   - **Joint venture**: Partner with a **local EU firm** to reduce scrutiny.

---
### **Bottom Line**
Your transaction will face **intense scrutiny** in all three jurisdictions, with **France likely the most interventionist** and the **Netherlands the most unpredictable**. While the **U.S. origin** of the investor helps, **energy criticality + deal size + cross-border structure** make this a **high-risk filing**. Early engagement with authorities and **proactive mitigation** (e.g., asset carve-outs, local oversight) will be critical to approval.

Would you like a deeper dive into **specific mitigation structures** (e.g., French "pacte d’actionnaires" or German trustee models)?

One day the American was visiting Rome, Italy and found multiple carts that were selling t shirts with the cartoon character on them. One of them had a different outfit than the cartoon's typical outfit with crazy sunglasses. A different rendition of the shirt had the character dress as a worker's right advocate related to a popular movement in Italy. Another shirt was a warped version of the character that mocked one of the famous jokes in the show. What can I do for my client in terms of defending his copyright in Italy? If he were to find the same shirts in the US, what would be the analysis under US law out of curiosity?

rubric.title: The response states that the user's client's copyright is automatically protected in Italy without registration.
rubric.description: This is critical.

rubric.title: The response states that the user's client's copyright is automatically protected in Italy partially because of the Berne Convention.
rubric.description: Berne convention is critical.

rubric.title: The response states that the Berne Convention requires a country to recognize the works of citizens of other member countries as if they were those of its own citizens.
rubric.description: Berne convention is highly relevant.

rubric.title: The response states that the user's client's copyright is automatically protected in Italy partially because of the WTO Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) Agreement.
rubric.description: Relevant law.

rubric.title: The response states that the TRIPS agreement requires member countries to provide baseline levels of IP protection for works of citizens from other member countries.
rubric.description: Important rule.

rubric.title: The response states that in Italy, there is typically copyright protection for a cartoon character as a "work of art".
rubric.description: Italian law on copyright protection is highly relevant.

rubric.title: The response states that in Italy, any derivative work (a work that modifies the original work) is a violation of copyright.
rubric.description: This is critical in Italian law.

rubric.title: The response states that in Italy, there are moral rights in copyright.
rubric.description: Moral rights are relevant.

rubric.title: The response states that the most common moral right in Italy is the right to integrity, which makes it a violation to associate a copyrighted work with a cause or act that it is not naturally associated with.
rubric.description: Right to integrity is highly relevant.

rubric.title: The response states that the T-shirt with a different outfit would be considered a copyright violation in Italy (as a derivative work).
rubric.description: Specific analysis on shirt.

rubric.title: The response states that the T-shirt with the workers' rights message would be considered a copyright violation as a derivative work in Italy.
rubric.description: Specific analysis.

rubric.title: The response states that the T-shirt with the workers' rights message would be considered a copyright violation as (most likely) a violation of the right of integrity in Italy.
rubric.description: Specific analysis.

rubric.title: The response states that the T-shirt with the warped mocking version of the character would be considered a copyright violation as a derivative work (and potentially a right of integrity violation) in Italy.
rubric.description: Specific analysis.

rubric.title: The response states that the main difference between US and Italian copyright law is the US fair use doctrine.
rubric.description: Fair use is critical.

rubric.title: The response states that US fair use allows for the use of copyrighted materials for certain purposes, such as commentary and comment.
rubric.description: Fair use is critical.

rubric.title: The response states that parody is a work that comments on the original work.
rubric.description: Important definition.

rubric.title: The response states that satire uses the original work as a vehicle to comment on a different issue.
rubric.description: Satire is important to understand.

rubric.title: The response states that the biggest factor of fair use is that it is transformative, meaning it adds additional meaning to the work.
rubric.description: Understanding fair use is relevant.

rubric.title: The response states that parody is much more likely to be considered fair use than satire.
rubric.description: Important distinction.

rubric.title: The response states that parody is much more likely to be considered fair use than satire because parody transforms the work itself, whereas satire just places the work in a different context.
rubric.description: This distinction is critical.

rubric.title: The response states that in the US, the one shirt that may be protected is the warped, mocking version of the character.
rubric.description: May be parody.

rubric.title: The response states that the warped, mocking shirt may be protected in the US as a fair use parody.
rubric.description: Fair use in US is relevant.

rubric.title: The response states that in both the US and Italy, the user's client should first send a cease and desist letter.
rubric.description: Correct first step.

rubric.title: The response states that if a cease and desist letter fails, the user's client could file a lawsuit.
rubric.description: Important option.

rubric.title: The response states that the user's client could ask for an injunction to stop the infringing activity (shirt sales).
rubric.description: Injunction is an important remedy.

rubric.title: The response states that the user's client could ask for damages for the infringing T-shirts.
rubric.description: Damages a a relevant remedy.

rubric.title: The response states that damages in Italy are typically the greater of the two: 1) damages based on the royalties that the infringer would've had to pay for a license or 2) profits the infringer actually made.
rubric.description: Damages calculation in Italy is relevant.

rubric.title: The response states that in the American system, the copyright holder could choose to pursue actual damages or statutory damages.
rubric.description: American system is relevant.

rubric.title: The response states that actual damages in the US are often based on either the lost licensing fee or the actual profits (whichever is greater typically).
rubric.description: Actual damages is relevant.

rubric.title: The response states that statutory damages could range from as low as $200 (if infringement was proven accidental) to $150,000 (if shown to be willful).
rubric.description: Statutory damages are relevant.

prompt: Belgium and Spain are both Contracting Parties to the attached “Convention on Conduct of Fishing Operations in the North Atlantic” (the “Convention”). Authorized officers from Belgium, upon seeing that lines anchored into the sea were not marked, identified and approached a Spanish vessel in order to request information about the vessel. The Spanish officers on board refused to cooperate with the Belgian officers. The Belgian officers then reported the Spanish vessel to a review board and argued that by refusing to cooperate, the Spanish officers on board further violated Spain's obligations under the Convention. Considering the attached document, draft an advisory email to Spain, explaining what the review board will likely decide.

attachments.path: documents/1382/Convention on Conduct of Fishing Operations in the North Atlantic.pdf

rubric.title: Recognizes that Spain is subject to the terms set forth in the Convention.
rubric.description: LAW: Convention on Conduct of Fishing Operations in the North Atlantic, p. 2 'The Governments of Belgium, Canada, Denmark, the French Republic, the Federal Republic of Germany, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, the Polish People's Republic, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, and the United States of America, Desiring to ensure good order and conduct on the fishing grounds in the North Atlantic area; Have agreed as follows . . .' PROMPT: 'Belgium and Spain are both Contracting Parties to the attached 'Convention on Conduct of Fishing Operations in the North Atlantic.'' ANALYSIS: A Contracting Party to the Convention signs and agrees to the terms of the Convention. Here, the prompt states that Spain is a Contracting Party to the Convention, so it is subject to its terms.

rubric.title: Identifies that under Article 5 of the Convention, lines anchored in the sea shall be marked in order to indicate their position.
rubric.description: LAW: Convention on Conduct of Fishing Operations in the North Atlantic, p.3 Article 5: 'Nets, lines and other gear anchored in the sea and nets or lines which drift in the sea shall be marked in order to indicate their position and extent. The marking shall be in accordance with the provisions of Annex IV to this Convention.'

rubric.title: Identifies that under Article 9(5) of the Convention, if an authorized officer has reason to believe that a vessel of any Contracting Party is not complying with the provisions of the convention, he may seek to obtain the necessary information from the vessel.
rubric.description: LAW: Convention on Conduct of Fishing Operations in the North Atlantic, p. 4 Article 9(5): 'If an authorised officer has reason to believe that a vessel of any Contracting Party is not complying with the provisions of the Convention, he may identify the vessel, seek to obtain the necessary information from the vessel and report. If the matter is sufficiently serious, he may order the vessel to stop and, if it is necessary in order to verify the facts of the case, he may board the vessel for enquiry and report.'

rubric.title: Notes that the Belgian officers had reason to believe that the Spanish vessel was not complying with the Convention.
rubric.description: LAW: Per C2/30301, lines anchored in the sea must be marked. PROMPT: 'Authorized officers from Belgium, upon seeing that lines anchored into the sea were not marked, identified and approached a Spanish vessel . . .' ANALYSIS: The Belgian officers saw lines anchored into the sea that were not marked near a Spanish vessel, which is a violation of Article 5 of the Convention.

rubric.title: Notes that the Belgian officers were acting in accordance with Article 9(5) of the Convention.
rubric.description: LAW: - Per C3/30297, under Article 9(5), if an authorized officer has reason to believe that a contracting party is in violation of the convention, they can seek to obtain necessary information from the vessel. - Per C4/30302, the Belgian officers had reason to believe that the Spanish vessel was not complying with Article 5 of the Convention. PROMPT: 'Authorized officers from Belgium, upon seeing that lines anchored into the sea were not marked, identified and approached a Spanish vessel in order to request information about the vessel.' ANALYSIS: The authorized officers from Belgium had reason to believe that Spain and its vessel were not in compliance with the Convention. Due to this belief, the Belgian officers requested information about the vessel, which is permissible under Article 9(5) of the Convention.

rubric.title: Identifies that under Article 14(3) of the Convention, a Contracting Party may reserve the right to not apply the terms set forth in Article 9(5).
rubric.description: LAW: Convention on Conduct of Fishing Operations in the North Atlantic, p. 6 Article 14(3): 'Any State may, at the time of signature, ratification, approval or accession, make a reservation to paragraphs (5) and (6) of article 9 with respect to one or more of the other Contracting Parties or signatory Governments.'

rubric.title: Identifies that Spain reserved the right to not apply the terms set forth in Article 9(5) with respect to all Contracting Parties.
rubric.description: LAW: Convention on Conduct of Fishing Operations in the North Atlantic, p. 10 'For the Government of Spain: With reservations in respect of paragraph 5 of article 13 and paragraphs 5 and 6 of article 9, applicable to all Contracting Parties and signatory Governments, as also to those Governments which shall in future accede to the Convention in accordance with article 17 thereof.' ANALYSIS: Because Spain reserved the right not to apply the terms set forth in Article 9(5) with respect to all Contracting Parties, that means that Spain reserved the right to not allow authorized officers of other Contracting Parties to request information about their vessels when the Contracting Party has reason to believe that they are not in compliance with the Convention (Article 9(5)).

rubric.title: Concludes that the review board will likely side with Spain.
rubric.description: LAW: - Per C5/30303, the Belgian officers were acting in accordance with Article 9(5). - Per C7/30305, Spain reserved the right to not apply the terms set forth in Article 9(5) with respect to all Contracting Parties. PROMPT: 'Draft an advisory email to Spain, explaining what the review board will likely decide.' ANALYSIS: The review board will likely side with Spain, because Spain reserved the right to not allow authorized officers of other Contracting Parties to request information about their vessels when the Contracting Party has reason to believe that they are not in compliance with the Convention (Article 9(5)). By refusing to cooperate with the Belgian officers, Spain did not violate their obligations under the Convention.

durch. Igor bleibt auch bei der Staatsanwaltschaft bei seinen Aussagen.  Igor wird ein Verteidiger bestellt und das Strafverfahren nimmt seinen Lauf. Sowohl 
der Beschuldigte als auch die Geschädigte Y werden von der Staatsanwaltschaft 
ausführlich einvernommen (inkl. direkter Konfrontation der Geschädigten mit dem 
Beschuldigten). Die Geschädigte Y konstituiert sich als Privatklägerin. Der 
Staatsanwalt erhebt schliesslich Anklage wegen zweifachen Raubs und versuchten 
Raubs. Das Hauptsachegericht lädt hernach zur Hauptverhandlung vor.  
Der Vorladung ist zu entnehmen, dass neben der Befragung der beschuldigten Person 
keine weiteren Beweisabnahmen geplant sind. Der Verteidiger von Igor hatte zuvor 
beim Gericht beantragt, dass auch die Geschädigte Y vom Gericht einzuvernehmen 
sei.  
Welche Argumente sprechen allgemein für und welche gegen die Unmittelbarkeit in der erstinstanzlichen Hauptverhandlung? Legen Sie die geltenden Regelungen und derzeitige Praxis dar und ordnen Sie sie ein.
reference_answers: In der Schweiz gilt das beschränkte Unmittelbarkeitsprinzip. Dies bedeutet, dass die Beweise überwiegend im Vorverfahren durch Polizei und Staatsanwaltschaft erhoben werden (vgl. Art. 350 Abs. 2 StPO). Diese haben sowohl belastende als 16 auch entlastende Beweise zusammenzutragen. Die Hauptverhandlung dient überwiegend der Kontrolle des Ergebnisses des Vorverfahrens. An der Hauptverhandlung führt die Verfahrensleitung die Einvernahmen durch. Zwingend zu befragen ist die beschuldigte Person. Diese Einvernahme hat eingehend (ausführlich) zu sein. Die Einvernahme hat Fragen zur Person, zur Anklage sowie zu den Ergebnissen des Vorverfahrens zum Gegenstand (Art. 341 Abs. 3 StPO). Zusätzlich erhebt das Gericht neue Beweise und ergänzt unvollständig erhobene Beweise. Beweise, welche durch Polizei oder Staatsanwaltschaft im Vorverfahren bereits erhoben wurden, erhebt das Gericht an der Hauptverhandlung im Beweisverfahren noch einmal, wenn diese im Vorverfahren nicht ordnungsgemäss erhoben wurden oder wenn sie im Vorverfahren zwar ordnungsgemäss erhoben wurden, aber die unmittelbare Kenntnis des Beweismittels für die Urteilsfällung notwendig erscheint (Art. 343 StPO). Dies geschieht von Amtes wegen, die Parteien haben aber selbstverständlich die Möglichkeit Beweisanträge zu stellen. Vorteil des schweizerischen Verfahrens ist, dass dieses sehr effizient ist und das Verfahren beschleunigt werden kann. Die Gerichtsverhandlungen sind um ein Vielfaches kürzer und der Organisationsaufwand geringer, zumal insbesondere nicht mehr alle Beteiligten wie Zeugen etc. noch einmal vor Gericht geladen und einvernommen werden müssen. Vielmehr kann sich das Gericht vorgängig über die Einvernahmeprotokolle (tlw. inkl. Videoaufzeichnung) seinen Eindruck verschaffen. Es kann dabei auch argumentiert werden, dass die Einvernahmen durch Polizei und Staatsanwaltschaft einen besseren Beweiswert haben als Einvernahmen vor Gericht, da sie zeitnah zur Tat erfolgt sind und das Erinnerungsvermögen der Befragten dann noch besser war. Als Nachteil des Schweizer Systems kann aufgeführt werden, dass das Gericht sich oft nur einen indirekten Eindruck verschafft, indem es seine Meinung aufgrund der Akten der Staatsanwaltschaft bildet. Insbesondere Einvernahmeprotokolle können den Eindruck verfälschen, zumal sie im Wesentlichen nur die Aussagen der einvernommenen Person wiedergeben, zwischenmenschliche Reaktionen aber nicht genau abgebildet werden können. Dies gilt umso mehr, als es zu den meisten Einvernahmen auch keine Videoaufzeichnungen gibt. Entgegengehalten werden könnte, dass die Gerichte durch Art. 343 Abs. 3 StPO Beweise vor Gericht noch einmal erheben müssen, wenn die unmittelbare Kenntnis für die Urteilsfällung notwendig erscheint. Die Praxis variiert von Kanton zu Kanton allerdings stark, obwohl Art. 343 StPO keine Kann-Vorschrift ist. Es ist bekannt, dass im Kanton Zürich Zeugen nur sehr zurückhaltend noch einmal vor Gericht befragt werden. Es besteht folglich die Gefahr, dass die StPO nicht einheitlich angewendet wird. Studien haben zudem gezeigt, dass Aktenkenntnis zu mehr Verurteilungen führt. Wird die Hauptverhandlung demgegenüber ohne Aktenkenntnis durchgeführt, gibt es mehr Freisprüche.

reference_answers:
Ex turpi causa defense 
Issue = to what extent auditors can assert the ex turpi causa defense to defeat the liquidator’s
claim of breach of duty of care
= question of the civil liability of auditors in the case of insolvency of the company
Case law: Moore Stephens v. Stone & Rolls Ltd (in liq)
Ex turpi causa defense = illegality defense
If wrongdoing is attributed to the company itself = like the company itself committed the
wrongdoing.
It is not possible for the company to rely on its own illegality to sue the auditors
= applies in cases where there are no innocent directors or shareholders

= Duty of care not owed to creditors even in the case of insolvency proceedings
Liquidator will not able to recover money for the creditors if auditors can assert the ex turpi
causa defense

i.c. Achille Taloon committed the wrongdoing: Achille Taloon willfully produced inaccurate

Specifically, the permits for developments in Punta Perotti, Bari were quashed due to a contravention of laws prohibiting construction in areas of natural interest, leading to land confiscation without compensation despite acquittals of involved parties for lack of criminal intent. Similarly, in Golfo Aranci and Reggio di Calabria, regional legislation changes imposed stricter building restrictions, rendering previously issued permits ineffective and resulting in site confiscation due to breaches related to building proximities to coastal areas and intended property uses. Although courts recognized some planning mistakes as excusable, the underlying issue remained unresolved until subsequent appeals and rulings led to varied outcomes including returned lands and ongoing compensation claims. Italy, nos. 18640/10 and 4 others, §§ 138-139, 4 March 2014; see also Kadubec v. Slovakia, 2 September 1998, § 57, Reports 1998-VI; Čanády v. Slovakia, no. 53371/99, § 31, 16 November 2004; and A. This principle has also been confirmed in terms of the right to the presumption of innocence under Article 6 § 2 of the Convention. Thus in the case of Mamidakis v. Greece (no. 35533/04, § 33, 11 January 2007) the Court found as follows:
“As to the complaint that the administrative courts did not take account of the fact that the applicant had not been prosecuted for the same offence, the Court takes the view that this situation cannot be analysed as a breach of the right to be presumed innocent. Such a finding would mean that no administrative proceedings could be brought in the absence of criminal proceedings and that no finding of an offence can be made by an administrative court in the absence of a formal declaration of guilt by a criminal court. In addition, the applicant has not raised any other argument which could lead the Court to conclude that the administrative courts had considered him to be guilty before reaching a final decision in his case.”

While the applicants emphasised the illegality of the confiscation measure in the absence of a formal conviction, the Government took the view that, except in the case of G.I.E.M. In sum, even supposing that the applicant committed one or more offences under the general law on 27 May 1944, the Court finds that their prosecution has been definitively statute barred since 1954 and that it would be contrary to the principle of foreseeability inherent in Article 7 of the Convention to punish him for these offences almost half a century after the expiry of the limitation period.
The Government submitted in the alternative that the applicant's conduct during the attack on Mazie Bati “was criminal according to the general principles of law recognised by civilised nations”, within the meaning of the second paragraph of Article 7 of the Convention. In that connection, the Court notes that on virtually every occasion the Convention institutions have examined a case under the second paragraph of Article 7, they have not considered it necessary also to examine it under the first paragraph (De Becker v. Belgium, no. 214/56, Commission decision of 9 June 1958, Yearbook 2, p. 214; X. v. Norway, no. 931/60, Commission decision of 30 May 1961, Collection of Decisions of the European Commission on Human Rights no. 6, p. 41; X. v. Belgium, no. 1028/61, Commission decision of 18 September 1961, Yearbook no. 4, p. 325; and Naletilić v. Croatia (dec.), no. 51891/99, ECHR 2000‑V, as also the decisions of X. v. Belgium (no. 268/57), Touvier and Papon (no. 2) cited above; for more extensive reasoning, see Penart v. Estonia (dec.), no. 14685/04, 24 January 2006, and the Kolk and Kislyiy decision cited above). The Court sees no reason to deviate from that approach in the present case. Since it has examined the case under the first paragraph of Article 7, it does not consider it necessary also to examine it under the second paragraph. In any event, even supposing that that paragraph was applicable in the instant case, the operation of 27 May 1944 cannot be regarded as “criminal according to the general principles of law recognised by civilised nations”.

There was, therefore, no plausible legal basis in international law on which to convict him of such an offence. Even supposing that the applicant has committed one or more offences under the general domestic law, their prosecution has long since become statute barred. Accordingly, domestic law could not serve as the basis for his conviction either.

Turning to the facts of the present case, the Court notes that the applicant was convicted under Article 148-1 § 7 of the Criminal Code, as worded since 13 January 1995, of tax offences which were committed in the period from 1993 to 1996. 
It observes that the application of the criminal law of 13 January 1995 to subsequent acts is not at issue in the instance case. The question to be determined is whether the extension of the law to acts committed prior to that date infringed the guarantee set forth in Article 7 of the Convention.

The Court, which is master of the characterisation to be given in law to the facts of the case, decided to examine the problem raised by the applicant under Article 7 of the Convention which is the relevant provision and which provides insofar as relevant as follows:
“1.  No one shall be held guilty of any criminal offence on account of any act or omission which did not constitute a criminal offence under national or international law at the time when it was committed. Nor shall a heavier penalty be imposed than the one that was applicable at the time the criminal offence was committed.”

At the outset, the Court reiterates that it is not its task to review in abstracto whether the retroactive application of the 2003 Code in war crimes cases is, per se, incompatible with Article 7 of the Convention. This matter must be assessed on a case-by-case basis, taking into consideration the specific circumstances of each case and, notably, whether the domestic courts have applied the law whose provisions are most favourable to the defendant (see Scoppola, cited above, § 109).

prompt: Select the continuation that best extends the ECHR argument excerpt.
context:
Facts:
The applicant, born in 1956, became the President of Lithuania on 26 February 2003. Shortly after taking office, he controversially granted Lithuanian citizenship to a Russian businessman, J.B., which was later challenged for breaching the Constitution. The Constitutional Court found that the decree violated the Constitution as J.B. had no exceptional merits justifying such a grant and had financially supported the applicant’s election campaign. Furthermore, the Court noted that the applicant acted under J.B.'s influence, disclosed state secrets, and exercised inappropriate influence over a private company. The Seimas initiated impeachment proceedings, and the Constitutional Court confirmed the applicant had grossly violated the Constitution and his oath of office. He was removed from his presidential position on 6 April 2004. An amendment to the Presidential Elections Act barred him from running for office, which was later upheld by the Constitutional Court, emphasizing that those removed through impeachment could never again assume presidential office. Subsequent legislative amendments further disqualified him from parliamentary positions. Although investigations into some allegations were dropped, he was acquitted of disclosing state secrets due to lack of evidence. J.B. was fined for attempting to coerce the applicant.

Arguments:
The Court reiterates that the purpose of Article 35 § 1 is to afford the Contracting States the opportunity of preventing or putting right the violations alleged against them before those allegations are submitted to it. Thus, the complaint to be submitted to the Court must first have been made to the appropriate national courts, at least in substance, in accordance with the formal requirements of domestic law and within the prescribed time-limits. Nevertheless, the only remedies that must be exhausted are those that are effective and capable of redressing the alleged violation (see, among many other authorities, Remli v. France, 23 April 1996, § 33, Reports 1996‑II). More specifically, the only remedies which Article 35 § 1 of the Convention requires to be exhausted are those that relate to the breaches alleged and at the same time are available and sufficient; the existence of such remedies must be sufficiently certain not only in theory but also in practice, failing which they will lack the requisite accessibility and effectiveness (see, for example, Selmouni v. France [GC], no. 25803/94, § 75, ECHR 1999-V). It falls to the respondent State, if it pleads non-exhaustion of domestic remedies, to establish that these various conditions are satisfied (see, among other authorities, Johnston and Others v. Ireland, 18 December 1986, § 45, Series A no. 112, and Selmouni, loc. cit.).
In the instant case the Court observes that in its ruling of 25 May 2004 the Constitutional Court held that a person who had been removed from the office of President for a gross violation of the Constitution or a breach of the oath could never again be elected President of the Republic or a member of the Seimas or hold an office for which it was necessary to take an oath in accordance with the Constitution. It follows from Article 107 of the Lithuanian Constitution that decisions of the Constitutional Court have statutory force and are final. Furthermore, as the Government pointed out in their written observations, the Constitutional Court itself is bound by its own precedents. An appeal against a refusal to register the applicant as a candidate for election to the Seimas would therefore have been bound to fail. Indeed, the Supreme Administrative Court's decision of 28 May 2004 provides an illustration of this point, since it attached decisive weight to the Constitutional Court's conclusions of 25 May 2004 in dismissing the applicant's complaint against the refusal of the Central Electoral Committee to register him as a candidate in the 2004 presidential election.
The Court also takes note of the Government's argument that the applicant could have made a prior request to the Constitutional Court for clarification of whether removal from office entailed lifelong disqualification from standing for election and that, if that position were confirmed, he could have resigned before the vote on whether to remove him from office. Such a request could not, however, have prompted an examination of the applicant's particular situation for the purposes of Article 3 of Protocol No. 1. It would also have required him to resign voluntarily as President and thereby to accept such a restrictive condition that the remedy in question could not in any event be regarded as “accessible”. It cannot therefore be classified as a domestic remedy that had to be used for the purposes of Article 35 § 1 of the Convention.

choices.text: The Court notes that the applicant raised this issue before the Appeal Court, which examined it, even though it did not refer to it in its judgment. Considering that the applicant has not further substantiated his claim, the Court finds no indication of any violation in this respect. It follows that this complaint must be rejected as being manifestly ill-founded within the meaning of Article 35 §§ 3 and 4 of the Convention.

The Court notes that the applicant did not raise the issue of Article 14 in any of the domestic proceedings, and has failed otherwise to challenge the different policies before the domestic courts. There is thus a real question as to whether the applicant has exhausted domestic remedies, as required by Article 35 of the Convention.
Under Article 35 § 1 of the Convention, the Court may only deal with the matter after all domestic remedies have been exhausted.
It follows from the foregoing that the Government have not shown that a domestic remedy satisfying the requirements of Article 35 § 1 of the Convention was available to the applicant.

context:
Facts:
The applicant, born in 1955 and residing in Switzerland, was involved in a lengthy custody dispute over his two children following their mother's move to Finland in 1993 with her new partner, L. After the mother's death in 1999, custody applications were lodged by both the applicant and L. Despite initial custody being awarded to the applicant by the District Court in 1999, the children expressed a strong wish to remain with L., citing a fear of moving to Switzerland. This preference was influenced by the strained relationship and litigation between the applicant and L. Upon appeal, the Finnish Court of Appeal maintained the decision that custody should be with the applicant but ensured a transitional visitation period. However, the Supreme Court eventually overturned this decision in 2001, granting custody to L. and emphasizing the children's mature unwillingness to move and the impracticality of enforcing such a transfer against their will. The applicant's requests for interim visits and psychological assessments of the children were deemed unnecessary, and the court highlighted the obligation of promoting a relationship between the children and their father under L.'s custody. Subsequent appeals by the applicant regarding foster home placement were dismissed, reaffirming custody with L. due to the best interests of the children.

Arguments:
Article 6 of the Convention provides as relevant:
“1.  In the determination of his civil rights and obligations ..., everyone is entitled to a fair and public hearing ... by an independent and impartial tribunal established by law. ...”
The applicant submitted that the evidence before the lower courts showed that the best interests of the children lay in giving custody to their father and that their opposition to this measure was based on views which had not been independently formed. The Supreme Court should not have reversed the lower court findings without convincing reasons and the applicant had had a right to be heard before it did so. Similarly before ruling on the alleged views of the children, who were caught in a conflict between adults, they should have been examined by experts who assess the reliability of their expressed wishes. He denied that his request for a hearing could be interpreted as conditional. That he wished to be heard was implicit in the request for all witnesses to be reheard; his counsel had merely objected to L.’s request that the children be examined by the court itself rather than an expert. He concluded that as a result the Supreme Court’s decision had been arbitrary.
As regarded Article 6, the Government pointed out that there was no absolute right to an oral hearing. The Supreme Court was under no obligation to do so under domestic law. It had been L. who had applied for an oral hearing. The applicant had only approached the matter conditionally, stating that if they granted L. an oral hearing he requested the court to rehear all the evidence from the lower courts. In the circumstances, he could reasonably be regarded as having waived his right to an oral hearing. The Supreme Court rejected L.’s request for a hearing as unnecessary. It was already accepted in both lower courts that L. and the applicant were fit custodians. As regarded the applicant’s request for the current psychological state of the children to be examined, it found this was also unnecessary as the children had firmly and consistently said that they wished to remain in a familiar environment with L. In their view, therefore, there was no unfairness disclosed by the procedure before the Supreme Court.

choices.text: The Court notes that the lack of an oral hearing was an essential, and integral, part of its finding of a violation of Article 8 of the Convention (see paragraph 58 above). In the circumstances of the present case no separate issue arises under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention.

Accordingly, the Court does not consider it necessary to ascertain whether the other requirements of paragraph 2 of Article 8 were complied with. Consequently the Court finds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention.

The Court observes, however, that it has examined essentially the same issues under Article 7 of the Convention. In the light of its finding of a violation of Article 7, it concludes that in the circumstances of the present case it is unnecessary to examine the applicant’s complaints under Articles 6, 13 and 17 of the Convention.

Bearing in mind its finding of a violation of Articles 3 and 8 of the Convention, the Court does not consider it necessary to examine whether the facts alleged also constituted deprivation of liberty within the meaning of Article 5.

prompt: Select the continuation that best extends the ECHR argument excerpt.
context:
Facts:
The case involves two applicants, a journalist and an editor-in-chief from the Helsingin Sanomat newspaper, and their publishing company, who were convicted for violating the privacy of a woman, O.T., by disseminating personal information in articles concerning a 2002 court judgment. Initially, a 2000 article in the Ilta-Sanomat newspaper had disclosed details about O.T.'s personal life during a presidential election campaign, which resulted in the conviction of the original article's journalist and editor-in-chief for privacy infringement. Subsequently, in February 2002, Helsingin Sanomat published articles about the court proceedings and the Forssa District Court's judgment, including previously mentioned personal details about O.T. Following complaints by O.T., the prosecutor charged the applicants, leading to a Vantaa District Court verdict on 3 November 2005, which found them guilty of disseminating private information. Appeals by the applicants, claiming an infringement of their free expression rights under Article 10 of the Convention, were unsuccessful at both the Helsinki Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court, which refused leave to appeal in December 2007.

Arguments:
The Court has already noted that a norm cannot be regarded as a “law” unless it is formulated with sufficient precision to enable the individual to regulate his conduct: he must be able - if need be with appropriate advice - to foresee, to a degree that is reasonable in the circumstances, the consequences which a given action may entail. Those consequences need not be foreseeable with absolute certainty: experience shows this to be unattainable. Again, whilst certainty is highly desirable, it may entail excessive rigidity and the law must be able to keep pace with changing circumstances. Accordingly, many laws are inevitably couched in terms which, to a greater or lesser extent, are vague and whose interpretation and application are a question of practice (see Sunday Times v. the United Kingdom (no. 1), 26 April 1979, § 49, Series A no. 30 and mutatis mutandis Kokkinakis v. Greece, 25 May 1993, § 40, Series A no. 260-A).
As concerns the provision in question at the relevant time, Chapter 24, section 8, of the Penal Code, the Court has already found in the Eerikäinen case (see Eerikäinen and Others v. Finland, no. 3514/02, § 58, 10 February 2009), in which the earlier provision of the Penal Code was at stake, namely that of Chapter 27, section 3(a), that it did not discern any ambiguity as to its contents: the spreading of information, an insinuation or an image depicting the private life of another person which was conducive to causing suffering qualified as invasion of privacy. Furthermore, the Court notes that the exception in the second sentence of the earlier provision concerning persons in a public office or function, in professional life, in a political activity or in another comparable activity is equally clearly worded (see Flinkkilä and Others v. Finland, no. 25576/04, § 66, 6 April 2010). The Court finds that the content of Chapter 24, section 8, of the Penal Code corresponds to the old Chapter 27, section 3(a), of the Penal Code as the amendments and clarifications made to the existing provision have been mainly technical (see and compare Lindon, Otchakovsky-Laurens and July v. France [GC], nos. 21279/02 and 36448/02, § 42, ECHR 2007‑XI).
While at the time when the articles in question were published, in February 2002, there were five Supreme Court decisions concerning the interpretation of the provisions in question, all of which concerned different aspects of private life, the Court finds that the possibility that a sanction would be imposed for invasion of private life was not unforeseeable. Even though there was no precise definition of private life in the preparatory works (see government bills HE 84/1974 and HE 184/1999), these works mentioned that the necessity of mentioning a person's name or other description of a person enabling identification was always subject to careful consideration. Had the applicants had doubts about the exact scope of the provision in question they should have either sought advice about its content or refrained from disclosing O.T.'s identity. Moreover, the applicants, who were professional journalists, could not claim to be ignorant of the content of the said provision since the Guidelines for Journalists and the practice of the Council for Mass Media, although not binding, provided even more strict rules than the Penal Code provision in question.

choices.text: This interference would contravene Article 10 of the Convention unless it was “prescribed by law”, pursued one or more of the legitimate aims referred to in paragraph 2 of Article 10, and was “necessary in a democratic society” for achieving such aim or aims. The Court will examine each of these criteria in turn.

The Court considers that, having regard to the circumstances of the present case, her complaint falls to be examined under Article 8 of the Convention (see X v. Finland, no. 34806/04, § 230, ECHR 2012 (extracts)), the relevant parts of which read as follows:
“1.  Everyone has the right to respect for his private ... life ...
2.  There shall be no interference by a public authority with the exercise of this right except such as is in accordance with the law and is necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security, public safety or the economic well-being of the country, for the prevention of disorder or crime, for the protection of health or morals, or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.”

The Court concludes therefore that the interference was “prescribed by law” (see Nikula v. Finland, no. 31611/96, § 34, ECHR 2002-II; Selistö v. Finland, no. 56767/00, § 34, 16 November 2004; Karhuvaara and Iltalehti v. Finland, no. 53678/00, § 43, ECHR 2004-X; Eerikäinen and Others v. Finland, cited above, § 58; and Flinkkilä and Others v. Finland, cited above, § 68, 6 April 2010). In addition, it has not been disputed that the interference pursued the legitimate aim of protecting the reputation or rights of others, within the meaning of Article 10 § 2.
3.  Whether the interference was necessary in a democratic society

It accordingly has to be determined whether the interference was justified under paragraph 2 of Article 8, in other words whether it was “in accordance with the law”, pursued one or more of the legitimate aims set out in that paragraph and was “necessary in a democratic society” to achieve the aim or aims in question.

context:
Facts:
The applicants in this case are a family born in Lebanon and Kuwait, except for the fifth applicant, who was born in Bulgaria and holds Bulgarian citizenship. The family sought asylum in Bulgaria in 2001 and was granted refugee status. The first applicant, the father, was later ordered to be expelled from Bulgaria on national security grounds in 2006 without detailed evidence provided at the time. This decision was based on allegations of involvement in drug trafficking, connections with extremist organizations, and other crimes. Despite attempts to contest the expulsion legally, including appeals to the Supreme Administrative Court, the order was upheld, citing national security. Subsequent requests for judicial review of his detention were mostly unsuccessful as the decisions were viewed as non-reviewable administrative actions. Eventually, attempts to deport him were halted due to inability to receive a travel document from the Lebanese Embassy and the applicant's inability to suggest a third country for removal. He was released in 2010 following internal reviews in light of legislative amendments. The family has remained in Bulgaria throughout this process.

Arguments:
The applicants complained that the order for the first applicant’s expulsion and its impending enforcement, as well as the first applicant’s detention pending such enforcement, amounted to an unlawful and unjustified interference with their right to respect for their family life. They relied on Article 8 of the Convention, which provides, in so far as relevant:
“1.  Everyone has the right to respect for his private and family life ...
2.  There shall be no interference by a public authority with the exercise of this right except such as is in accordance with the law and is necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security, public safety or the economic well‑being of the country, for the prevention of disorder or crime, for the protection of health or morals, or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.”
The Government submitted that the measures taken against the first applicant pursued a legitimate aim and were necessary. The Contracting States were entitled to expel an alien regardless of his or her level of integration. The first applicant’s removal from Bulgaria would not impose a disproportionate burden on the applicants, because they would be able to continue their family life outside the country. The circumstances in which the first applicant’s expulsion had been ordered showed that the authorities had not failed to strike a balance between the applicants’ rights and the public interest; they had carried out their duty to protect public order and national security. The expulsion order had not yet been put into effect, and the applicants’ family life could not therefore be regarded as already affected by it. The first applicant’s detention pending removal had not been disproportionate either, because the other applicants had been able to visit him in custody.
The applicants did not comment on the effects of the enforcement of the order for the first applicant’s expulsion on their family life. They submitted that the first applicant’s detention, which had lasted in total more than twenty‑two months, had been in breach of their right to respect for their family life, because it had been unlawful, in particular because of the first applicant’s refugee status; too lengthy; unnecessary; and not subject to judicial review. The first applicant had at all times remained at the authorities’ disposal and had not tried to flee. He could have been simply required to report to the police on a daily basis instead of being detained. That would have allowed him to remain with his family and to take care of his minor children.

choices.text: The Court considers that this complaint is not manifestly ill‑founded within the meaning of Article 35 § 3 (a) of the Convention or inadmissible on any other grounds. It must therefore be declared admissible.

In the light of all the material in its possession, the Court finds that these complaints do not disclose any appearance of a violation of the rights and freedoms set out in the Convention or its Protocols. Accordingly, this part of the application must be rejected as manifestly ill-founded and declared inadmissible pursuant to Article 35 §§ 3 (a) and 4 of the Convention.

The Court notes that the applicant raised this issue before the Appeal Court, which examined it, even though it did not refer to it in its judgment. Considering that the applicant has not further substantiated his claim, the Court finds no indication of any violation in this respect. It follows that this complaint must be rejected as being manifestly ill-founded within the meaning of Article 35 §§ 3 and 4 of the Convention.

The Court considers that this part of the application raises questions of law which are sufficiently serious that their determination should depend on an examination of the merits. No other ground for declaring it inadmissible has been established. The application must therefore be declared admissible. Pursuant to Article 29 § 3 of the Convention, the Court will consider the merits of this complaint below.
